column4: it's not up to the author of the program to decide how many cores to use
all the program author does is spawn so and so many threads, and the kernel decides which cores are used and how many

some toolkits, such as the version of cocoa that's arriving in Mac OS X 10.5 Leopard can actually be called asynchronously, so program authors don't need to do anything but still get a lot of GUI code moved to a seperate thread
